Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (Landlord & Tena.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a landlord implicitly covenants to provide the tenant with quiet enjoyment and the right to possess and use the leased premises without substantial interference.

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a landlord implicitly covenants to provide the tenant with quiet enjoyment and the right to possess and use the leased premises without substantial interference.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary.raw_text: 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code: Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary.proposition: The landlord’s obligation is complemented by state sanitary and housing standards that define minimum requirements for heating and habitability.

105 CMR 410.700 (Heating requirements).proposition: The landlord’s obligation is complemented by state sanitary and housing standards that define minimum requirements for heating and habitability.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: Where a landlord fails to provide reliable heat as required by applicable standards or where recurrent substantial interference with heat substantially defeats the tenant’s ability to use the premises, the landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment and may be liable for damages.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide essential services such as heat can constitute a breach of the *implied warranty of habitability*, and that such a breach can be raised as a defense to unlawful detainer and can reduce rent/damages. However, the opinion does not frame the heating problem as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it analyze landlord liability under that covenant. The controlling doctrinal hook here is the warranty of habitability, not quiet enjoyment, so the case does not support the specific proposition as worded.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. This implied warranty of habitability does not require that a landlord ensure that leased premises are in perfect, aesthetically pleasing condition, but it does mean that ‘bare living requirements’ must be maintained. In the instant case…[defects included]…lack of heat in four rooms… If the trial court does find a breach of implied warranty, the court must then determine the extent of the damages flowing from this breach.”

Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..raw_text: Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp., 439 F.2d 477 (D.C. Cir. 1971)
Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..proposition: Where a landlord fails to provide reliable heat as required by applicable standards or where recurrent substantial interference with heat substantially defeats the tenant’s ability to use the premises, the landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment and may be liable for damages.
Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..case_name: Sarah B. Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Avenue Apartment Corporation
Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..support_reasoning: The case concerns a landlord’s duty to take reasonable protective measures against foreseeable criminal acts in common areas of a large apartment building. It does not address heating, building code heat requirements, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss recurrent interference with heat as a breach. The opinion’s contractual discussion refers to security measures, not habitability via heat, so using Kline as authority for a heat/quiet-enjoyment proposition misstates its holding and reasoning.
Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..relevant_excerpt: “This court noted that the value of the lease to the modern apartment dweller is that it gives him ‘a well known package of goods and services — a package which includes not merely walls and ceilings, but also adequate heat, light and ventilation, serviceable plumbing facilities, secure windows and doors, proper sanitation, and proper maintenance.’… In the case at bar we place the duty of taking protective measures guarding the entire premises and the areas peculiarly under the landlord's control against the perpetration of criminal acts upon the landlord…”

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Where a landlord fails to provide reliable heat as required by applicable standards or where recurrent substantial interference with heat substantially defeats the tenant’s ability to use the premises, the landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment and may be liable for damages.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion does not analyze failures of heat as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; instead, it adopts and applies an implied warranty of habitability framework. The court discusses heat only as one of several essential services encompassed by that warranty and addresses landlord liability and damages in contract terms, expressly displacing constructive eviction/quiet enjoyment doctrine rather than grounding relief in it. Thus, it supports liability and damages for lack of heat under an implied warranty of habitability, not under the covenant of quiet enjoyment as the proposition states.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt:
[T]hey seek a well known package of goods and services—a package which includes not merely walls and ceilings, but also adequate heat, light and ventilation, serviceable plumbing facilities, secure windows and doors, proper sanitation, and proper maintenance.

... we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation.

Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..raw_text: Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979)
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..proposition: Material interference may be proved by showing a recurring, persistent deficiency that significantly impairs the habitability or comfort of the dwelling, including inadequate heat during the heating season.
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines the scope of the implied warranty of habitability as covering conditions that materially affect health and safety, and uses “insufficient heat” as an explicit example of such essential services whose significant deficiency would breach the warranty. While the facts of the case concern garbage, vermin, and sanitation during a strike rather than heat, the court’s general statement of the standard supports the proposition that recurring, substantial deficiencies in essential services (including inadequate heat during the heating season) that significantly impair habitability or comfort can constitute material interference. Thus, the case provides direct doctrinal support for the proposition’s principle regarding material interference and inadequate heat.
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..relevant_excerpt: “A residential lease is essentially a sale of shelter and necessarily encompasses those services which render the premises suitable for the purpose for which they are leased… he does warrant, however, that there are no conditions that materially affect the health and safety of tenants. For example, no one will dispute that health and safety are adversely affected by insect or rodent infestation, **insufficient heat and plumbing facilities**, significantly dangerous electrical outlets or wiring, inadequate sanitation facilities or similar services which constitute the essence of the modern dwelling unit.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (Summary Process.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (Summary Process) (jurisdictional and procedural provisions applicable to landlord/tenant disputes)
